lead_paragraph: ''SUBTERRANEAN warfare may be the answer for the enemies of the United States,'' wrote Maj. Donald M. Helig in a research paper for the Air Command and Staff College at Maxwell Air Force Base in Alabama last year.Over the past 100 years, subterranean warfare has evolved from a tactic to evade potential enemies into an extremely effective and efficient means to counter the effects of superior air power. But seeking refuge --and strategic advantage --underground has a much longer history than that.
abstract: Caves and tunnels have been turned to military use for thousands of years, and US forces faced 'worm warfare' in Vietnam and Korea before Taliban and terrorists took to their caves in Afghanistan; drawings (M)
